item.title: Tomatillo
item.description:
I bought a little box of tomatillos from Argus Farm Stop. The question now is what to do with them.

Suggestions so far include:

  • fried like green tomatoes, slice thin, coat with a thin batter
  • roasted them with onions and jalapenos and make into a salsa
  • raw tomatillo salsa a la Rick Bayless
  • fried with onions and then add to scrambled eggs for tortillas
  • baked shrimp with tomatillos, feta, and cilantro
  • carne en su jugo, a la La Fiesta Mexicana in Ypsilanti
  • in pastel de Montezuma

What I ended up making was a very simplified version of Tomatillo Breakfast Tacos, reducing the recipe to just onions, tomatillos, and eggs. Cook chopped onions and chopped tomatillos over medium heat (6 of 10) until the tomatillos are soft and the onions are browned, about 12 minutes. Crack some eggs over the top of the mixture and cover. Cook without stirring until the eggs are set to your desired doneness.

More discussion and commentary on Facebook. Note that Twitter did not supply a good stream of answers, but it did unearth the one recipe I actually used, so there’s that.

item.title: make tidy
item.description:
I’ve been converting over old postings on this blog from Typepad. The data export and import was imperfect, and this meant that I’ve been poring over the data to figure out what keeps and what goes and what-not. It’s a chance to review old words.

One of the artifacts of the old hosting platform was a helpful at times system called Zemanta. Zemanta would figure out what you were writing about and give you helpful suggestions for related links, both to things that you had written as well as to things other people had written.

I’ve decided as part of the transformation of the old weblog into the new one to unlink those “related links”, in the hope that eventually Hugo’s own system will create some either algorithmically derived relations or at least an easier way to do that by hand.

In the meantime I’m looking closely at what Zemanta did so I can undo it. The first set of artifacts is a “fieldset” with its links, and that’s easy enough to search and destroy. Occasionally but not always I find my links decorated with a class="zem_slink" marker that’s a little harder to find. Most insidious so far was exactly one time where Zemanta (or Typepad) rewrote or wrote an Amazon link to include an affiliate link points to Zemanta, and not to me.

Rewriting 1500+ pages is going to take a while. The biggest question is unpublishing some of them, since time has passed and I don’t need to republish everything. There’s conversion from HTML to Markdown to remove the uglies, spelling errors to catch, next categories and taxonomies to fill, layout to work on, etc. At some point I need to sort out image management. But first I’m going to understand the consequences of previous convenience decisions I made to use Zemanta and to undo that decision.

A few months ago I wrote a tiny R script that generates maps. The challenge today is to find a portable environment so that I can deploy this script on shared infrastructure. The project took 30 minutes of MacBook Air processor time running full blast parallel, and while I don’t care about wall clock time to complete the effort I do care about building something that I can hand off to someone else to run.

The hope is that the ropensci Docker package from the Rocker project is the answer, or most of the answer, for this. Rocker has built R images where lots of useful packages have been installed, including systems where the install directions are a little bit complex.

With all complicated software environments the biggest challenge is dealing with dependencies. If you want to use the latest and greatest fast algorithms, you have to be prepared to spin up on what the cool kids are doing in the rest of their environment. If somehow you can jump to the edge of the development in the algorithm world without being tripped up by the hairy dependency graph that got you there, it can be a lot more fun.

So; install Docker on the Mac with ‘boot2docker’; then

docker pull rocker/ropensci
docker run -it rocker/ropensci R

and poof, you have an environment current to this month’s desktop of leading R developers.

item.title: Starting a trial of Little Bird
item.description:
Little Bird is a system that helps you discover influencers and experts in any topic. I’m at the very start of a 7 day trial. Marshall Kirkpatrick is CEO of Little Bird, and he has been active on Twitter posting interesting ideas about influence marketing - and given that it seemed prudent to give the product a try.

Pricing is aimed at agencies, not individuals, so I’m going to look at this product through the eyes of people doing “social listening” for a living, tracking the messages that appear on a topic and either quietly making sense of what is happening or actively engaging with those people to try to influence their opinions. The single user price is out of my reach for an annual commitment, though I might keep it up for another month if I can find a specific task that warrants the extra tooling.

My first test with any social software is to point it at a domain that I know (Ann Arbor) and see what it unearths. Little Bird found for me 1000 influential accounts having to do with Ann Arbor, and in a boost to my ego it puts me in the top 50. Without understanding how the algorithms work it seems that it biases towards identifying busy accounts that post a lot of news, vs. the clever individual whose every post is good but who doesn’t post that often.

There’s a style of posting which I would have to describe as “thinkfluential” which Little Bird has a nose for. The thinkfluencer will post frequently on a given topic, and a lot of people will retweet them and they will retweet a lot of people. Every message is relentlessly on message and you won’t find cat pictures or meeting banter mixed in. More often than not you’ll see the thinkfluence augmented by robots that post newsy things day and night, even when the thinkfluencer is away from the keyboard. There doesn’t even need to be any interaction at all with this “expert”, just a never-ending confluence of thinkfluence.

So I wish that Little Bird had another round of filters, to help me understand the question at scale “is this person really a bot”. The real utility for me of identifying expertise is not to pick out the high-frequency posting bot, but to suss out who on a topic is good at engaging on the things they know about. Bot identification is the Turing Test at work, and maybe just maybe there’s a set of computable metrics that you can build across a corpus of Twitter users to pull that out.

item.title: Library notes from Malletts Creek
item.description:
Out for a bike ride to Malletts Creek Branch Library after a delicious lunch of BBQ at Ricewood.

One of the challenges of low overhead custom postcard making is getting an image manipulation pipeline that kicks out photos that a appropriately cropped and sized. The latest challenge is identifying the single command line that will turn a photo from my phone’s camera into an appropriately sized image for the card with a minimum of cropping, distortion, and manual file transfers.

What I know doesn’t work is upload via Twitter, because the series of resizings generate visible compression artifacts.

I can upload from the phone to OneDrive, which gives me a photo of size 2592 × 1456 pixels (1.78:1, 16:9). The target size is 1875 x 1275 (1.47:1, 25:17), which is postcard format. I can keep all of the pixels in the image by letterboxing it, or I can crop off the edges. What I can’t really do is stretch the image to fit because it’s too far off.

Looking further at my camera software (Lumia Camera) it appears that I can also take photos at 4:3. There’s more experimenting to be done.

For more documentation, see Efficient Image Resizing With ImageMagick, Dave Newton in Smashing Magazine, June 25, 2015. Dave goes through a professionally thorough view of resizing and resampling images for the web, comparing his results against Photoshop. For instance:

I tested 31 different settings for -filter and got the best results with Triangle. The Triangle resampling filter is also known as bilinear interpolation, which I discussed above. It determines pixel color by looking at a support area of neighboring pixels and produces a weighted average of their colors. I found it best to specify this support area at two pixels using the -define filter:support=2 setting.

Dave uses DSSIM from https://pornel.net/dssim to test his results.

This tool computes (dis)similarity between two PNG images using (my approximation of) algorithms approximating human vision. Comparison is done in La*b color space using a multi-scale variant of the SSIM algorithm.

There are sites that have automatic crop algorithms, though I haven’t yet found a package that’s usable without licensing. The interactive web site of Croppola is one useful example of this genre.

Pittsburgh’s smallest jazz club is installed in a bus stop on Liberty Avenue, across from 9th Street. The shelter was installed on July 6 and will remain until late August 2015. From the New Pittsburgh Courier Online:

Awesome Pittsburgh’s trustees smiled unanimously when they decided to choose the proposal for one of 2014’s $1000 grants, envisioning a bus patron who pushes a button, only to have an iPod play jazz music from one of MCG Jazz’s Grammy Award winning recordings. The interior walls of a bus shelter will feature images of Pittsburgh’s jazz legends, and a blank “Your Face Here!” space to take a picture of yourself at “Pittsburgh’s Smallest Jazz Club.” Lamar Outdoor, owner of the bus shelters in Pittsburgh and Allegheny County, is already on board to help make the project happen.

The project was done by MCG Jazz - Amy Kline is their marketing manager.

Network issues at Malletts Creek branch were a good reason to exit back towards town.

item.title: Daily Coffee and Wifi, Roos Roast Wednesday edition
item.description:
At Roos, an espresso over ice with a little half and half and a hard boiled egg. It’s a very compact breakfast. The espresso is served in an appropriately sized glass mug and tastes like the strongest little iced latte you will ever have.

On my Mac, run ‘boot2docker upgrade’. That gets me up to current 1.7.1 revision of everything.

Edwards-MacBook-Air:~ emv$ docker version
Client version: 1.7.1
Client API version: 1.19
Go version (client): go1.4.2
Git commit (client): 786b29d
OS/Arch (client): darwin/amd64
Server version: 1.7.1
Server API version: 1.19
Go version (server): go1.4.2
Git commit (server): 786b29d
OS/Arch (server): linux/amd64

The issue that 1.7.1 resolves for me is certificate support - if I understand the bug right, the Docker daemon was creating a key for each interface it had, but not all of the interfaces were up at key init time. The fix was to move DHCP init earlier in the start sequence so that everything was initialized by the time key creation took place.

The Docker team is trying to improve code quality by having their code base pass the golint test. The open issue, fix golint errors/warnings #14784, has attracted a swarm of contributors, and a lot of them have proposed changes that don’t pass the automated tests. The build farm is managed with Jenkins, and you can see the status of every build of Docker on their dashboard.

Having a full lintable codebase is a great goal. The challenge comes when the suggested changes by lint send you in the direction of making an incompatible change to some interface that has the “wrong” name but that people were relying on.

Perhaps importantly for the work I’m doing it’s worth noting that currently all of these tests are done on x86 platforms (Linux and Windows) and there isn’t an official automated build on ARM. I’ve been using the Docker distribution from Hypriot as my baseline for working on the Raspberry Pi, with good success.

Construction on I-75 at 13 Mile Road! Expect major delays at this project in Madison Heights. From the Oakland Press

During the construction project, there will be lane closures on both I-75 and 13 Mile Road in Madison Heights, said Diane Cross, a spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Transportation, which is doing the work.

(insert map here)

None of the alternative routes look any good, allow extra time for travel.

Components of the postcard project are coming together. So far I have little pieces that put and get addresses from a database, resize pictures to the correct size, and generate test and live cards.

If I lob a single thoughtful card out every time I have an espresso, there will be some steady stream of cards going out. Next piece of the checklist is pulling a report showing which cards are in flight and which ones just arrived so that I can schedule followups.

One of the key bits of sending cards is that your recipient doesn’t get them right away. That gives you a chance to refine your thinking and contemplate what you have to say when you do follow up when they do get it.

item.title: bocker is a subset of Docker in 100 lines of shell script
item.description: bocker is Docker (or at least a good sized subset of it) in 100 lines of shell script. I suppose the point is that even though there’s a huge world of hype surrounding containerization as a next step of systems management, when you get down to it, it’s just not that complicated.

item.title: Coworking notes at Elixir Vitae
item.description:
A productive afternoon with Mohan Kartha in which I opened a great many tabs in Chrome. This bit of writing to close those out. Elixir Vitae is a great spot for writing - lots of quiet noise from the coolers to keep a background hum, and close to the bus station.

I’m sorting out the simplest task that I’d like to do with Node-RED, now that I have a Raspberry Pi 2 running it under Docker in a configuration that’s reliable enough that it seems like it’s stable. The easiest network test in the world is the ping test, and so my first stab at a try for “run always” is a simple configuration to notice when the network looks like it’s down and when it is to collect some more detailed information and log it to a file.

The inspiration for that is this simple configuration from an idea by Nathan Chantrell, implemented by Martin Harizanov in 2014. Presence detection using phone’s WiFi and Node-RED relies on static IP address assignments from DHCP, plus “ping”, to notice if someone’s device is in the building, turned on, and listening to wifi.

I’ve had enough phones drain their battery to know that absence of a wifi signal is not an unambiguous marker!

Fantelope is doing a beta product launch at the final AFC Ann Arbor minor league soccer game of the year, Saturday, July 25 at 6 PM at Hollway Field (Pioneer High School, 601 W. Stadium, Ann Arbor). See the Fantelope web site for more details.

My first pass at writing code to send postcards from Lob.com is working. The note to self is that if you have a square bracket in a URL, that you have to turn off curl’s globbing function, e.g. with -g or –globoff. “When you set this option, you can specify URLs that contain the letters {}[] without having them being interpreted by curl itself. “

Every card has a tracking code, so the next bit of reporting to write is to see which cards are awaiting printing, which ones are in transit, where they are going to and whether they have been received.

The AAATA moved the endpoint URL for its old-school “classic” mobile RideTrak application. To go to a particular route like the 5, see e.g. http://mobile.theride.org/classic/rideguide_m.asp?route=5 . The main http://mobile.theride.org has a newer interface, but alas my Windows Phone 8.1 with its Internet Explorer browser doesn’t do that page justice. (That, and I prefer the old interface because I managed to figure it out for the stop I’m always catching the bus from.)

Little Bird promises to “help businesses unlock the valuable information in structured social data”. I’ve asked for a trial to see what they have in store.

I’m wondering what the best approach is to the task of “download all of my email from Gmail”, since the storage I now have available on my laptop would make it straightforward to have an 18 GB personal mail spool and because I really actually would love to search through it so that I can mark some messages for permanent deletion. One possibility is Enkive from The Linux Box.

I am reminded that I want to carry around a set of headphones with me that plug into my Nokia 635 so that I can use the phone as a radio, and also reminded that I want to try to construct a headphone dipole as an antenna for my NooElec DVB-T tuner. The challenge will be remembering those desires at the right time so that when I see the parts I need in the junk pile at home that I can grab what I need for my every day carry bag.

Oh, and I need to track down an 8 GB USB stick to load a boot ISO on.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi, ERC South Main
item.description:
Espresso over ice at ERC South Main. This is now my favorite summer drink. Served in a cup with enough ice and you get the makings of a very strong iced latte, just add a little half and half.

The work of the morning is finishing up yesterday’s work on sending postcards with Lob.com. Key to this effort is resizing your favorite images so that they meet the template. Fortunately I had the presence of mind seven years ago to write up my notes on using sips and Imagemagick for image manipulation and that helped. In this case the magic incantation was

sips -z 1275 1875 original.jpg --out new.jpg

If you don’t have a Mac, or want to do this on a server or container somewhere, you’ll want Imagemagick. That venerable program has a bazillion options, and you’ll find the image geometry options at http://www.imagemagick.org/script/command-line-processing.php#geometry . Recreating this exact sips command is left as an exercise for the reader.

That bit of image processing taken care of, the next iteration is to launch a few actual postcards into the ether. After having confirmed that everything goes OK on the test key, I sent out four cards. Estimated delivery date is July 30, so I’m expecting about a two week turnaround for feedback that I got everything right. Lob has card tracking so I guess the next step is to write the simple tools to know when things were delivered so that I can plan some phone calls.

My cousin Zorba has perhaps the best bio in the business.

He has, in the course of his endeavors: been shot at by Navajos in Utah; seized and threatened at knifepoint by rednecks in Arkansas; chased by AK-47-toting soldiers in Hungary; run out of town by the Penitentes in Truchas; shaken down by the Federales in Baja, and forced to be rude to secure a cab in Rome. He has hung out of and over: planes, balloons, helicopters, boats, rafts, race cars, elevator shafts, too tall cliffs, and real deep canyons- and yet, he still has enthusiasm and a good attitude.

Jerry Davis asks why we still have academic journals:

The Web has greatly reduced the barriers to entry for new journals and other platforms for communicating scientific output, and the number of journals continues to multiply. This leaves readers and authors with the daunting cognitive challenge of navigating the literature and discerning contributions that are both relevant and significant. Meanwhile, measures of journal impact that might guide the use of the literature have become more visible and consequential, leading to “impact gamesmanship” that renders the measures increasingly suspect.

The essay, published in Administrative Science Quarterly in June 2014, has the seeds of its own answer. Journals exist to enrich academic publishers.

Pay per Article - You may purchase this article for US$32.00. You must download your purchase, which is yours to keep, within 24 hours.

I’ll just ask Jerry for a preprint.

Previously (1995!) I get quoted in the Times Higher Education Supplement. The debate then centered around Stevan Harnad, an open access journal advocate who saw clearly the trend towards low cost electronic publications, thusly:

It remains only to tally up these PostGutenberg values: If the world’s esoteric scholarly/scientific literature were available to everyone for free in electronic form, the first benefit to the author would be the great increase in the visibility, accessibility and hence the potential impact of his work (1). This would of course also be a benefit to all scholars when they are wearing their readers’ rather than their authors’ hats (2). Some fear that such a literature would be overwhelming and un-navigable, but stop and think: How do we currently manage it in paper? If the entire corpus were transferred to the Net, instead of our eyes and fingers and feet doing the walking to get to the papers or to get the papers to us, electronic directories containing everything could be searched using the kinds of keyword search already used today in searching electronic databases that contain the titles and abstracts (but not the articles) in the paper literature. Then, one more click, and you have the paper itself! Or clever “knowbots” (automatic search programmes) could be designed to go out instead of us and look for papers fitting our profile of interests, leaving us even more time to actually read what we want and to do our research, rather than running after the literature.

My reply, immortalized from the past

Edward Vielmetti (bottom) uncontroversially points out that there is a lot of rubbish on the Internet; but he is sceptical of peer review as a solution.

The original commentary is lost in the mists of time, I hope.

There are two institutions that went by the name of GopherCon. (No, it’s not a furry convention; that’s Anthrocon.) One was from the early 1990s surrounding the Gopher internet browsing protocol; the other is for enthusiasts and programmers of the Go programming language. I am not aware of anyone who can claim to have gone to both events.

GopherCon 1995 featured discussion of GopherVR and VRML for virtual reality in Gopher, the Hyper-G Information System for hypertext authoring, and an early morning session on Integrating Gopher and WWW.

GopherCon 2015 was in early July in Colorado. Of the items on the agenda this talk by Barak Michener was perhaps the most interesting to follow through on:

Written in Go, Cayley is a graph database based on technology behind Freebase.com. Starting with a short history of the inspirations behind Cayley, this talk will deep-dive into the moving parts of building a graph database, between the various query languages, the storage engines, and the iterator trees.

And of course this blog is now powered by Hugo which is written in Go so I’m learning a little about the Go template language as a side effect.

item.title: Commuter North and South
item.description:
A bus labeled “TRAINING”. Don’t take that one.

Kayakers in bright yellow kayaks on the Huron River under the bridge on Fuller Road.

Would it be too much to ask to have wifi actually on the blue bus, or is it more reasonable to expect that people have cell data coverage everywhere and that wifi on the bus is for long haul buses like Megabus?

I’m happy that with Hugo I can have a reasonably complete local blogging environment completely independent of having Internet access, so long as I have my computer with me. On the other hand doing live-blogging from a phone is not possible, not that it ever really was very practical with any previous setup).

“Your UMARC shack access code is …” Achievement unlocked.

The todo list right now for the shack is very short - “get in”. Now that I’m in I should have a longer list. There is a lot of gear in that room to get familiar with, not least of which is HF equipment with tunable and movable antennas.

Why Twitter Has More Freedom To Innovate Than Google is a 2013 Wired Magazine writeup. Prominently featured are Marius Eriksen, Niels Provos, and Peter Honeyman.

This was in the early aughts, when Eriksen was an undergrad at Michigan, studying computer science under a professor and lovable eccentric named Peter Honeyman. Known as “Dr. Honey” among the undergrads and PhD students at his Center for Information Technology Integration, Honeyman was famous for making assignments without really making assignments. “He would develop a particular obsession, and he would give you random hints about it, but he wouldn’t actually tell you what to do,” Eriksen remembers. “You would end up collaborating with people on whatever it was, in this freeform way, without much direction at all.”

I talked to one of Peter’s current students. Evan is looking at ways to direct RF energy at devices to make them fail in interesting ways.

Stanford, Berkeley, and the University of Michigan are working on the Secure Internet of Things Project (slashdot):

Stanford, Berkeley, and the University of Michigan have now started the Secure Internet of Things Project, which aims to promote security and transparency for IoT devices. They hope to unite regulators, researchers, and manufacturers to ensure nascent internet-connected tech is developed in a way that respects customer privacy and choice.

The web site has more details at http://iot.stanford.edu .

Among the presentations at the Secure Internet of Things Project Retreat in Half Moon Bay on June 5, 2015 was this by U of Michigan’s Prabal Dutta, State of the Field: Hardware and Systems.

(embed deck here, if I can)

The LP0965 Antenna is a Log Periodic PCB directional antenna, at 5-6dBi Gain. The design is from Kent Britain WA5VJB, and a data sheet for the antenna describes its utility for signals from 850 Mhz to 6500 Mhz. See http://wa5vjb.com for more circuit board antennas for use for hobby, wifi, microwave and cellular use.

Traffic jam on Fuller on the return trip, backed up all the way to the river. It took about 15 minutes to get through because of construction on westbound Fuller taking traffic to one lane. It would have been faster to take the Route 1 AAATA bus via Pontiac Trail, even though it would have been a considerable detour, or to walk to Plymouth Road and take the 2 in.

There was a fire at the Michigan League this afternoon. No sign of any issues as I pass by this evening.

The question when taking Commuter South is always where to get off the bus. Today I’ll take it all the way to the end of its route.

item.title: Daily coffee and wifi at Biggby Packard
item.description:
It’s a warm but pleasant mid-summer late Monday morning, and I’m visiting the first cafe inbound on a walk to town. Biggby Packard is where I end up when the inbound bus schedule timing is just so.

Summertime cafes near campus are odd. There’s not really enough here to motivate someone to drive here for coffee, so it draws people from the surrounding neighborhood and from the athletic campus. I’ve been in here before when I was the only patron for more than an hour but this morning there’s a few more people sitting typing.

I first ran into the “pocketmod” planning technique in 2005, and here it is 10 years later and there’s one in my pocket.

A pocketmod is a cleverly folded piece of paper with preprinted templates for things like a mini calendar, todo list, quadrille paper, checklist etc. It’s the smallest instance of a PDA that I have seen yet, requiring nothing more than a blank piece of paper and a pair of scissors to execute. You could even bypass the scissors if you had good paper and a crisp straightedge to do a rip.

Astoundingly, http://www.pocketmod.com/ is still online, in all of its 2005-2007 glory. That system does an 8-up PDF from a set of templates, so that you can print a lovingly detailed mini booklet. My own use has long since devolved into scrap paper plus rip down the center. When it fills up, invert the fold, and you have a brand new organizer.

Now playing, Johnny Cash’s “One Piece at a Time”. “GM wouldn’t miss just one little piece.” Look for the promo photo.

Menu plan: green beans with walnuts and miso sauce, plus a few green beans uncooked on the side for J who likes to eat the raw. A recipe of sorts is at The Kitchn, which refers to a 2005 New York Times Dining article about Yumiko Kano and her brand of Japanese cooking. Just Bento has some reviews of books by Yumiko Kano (aka Yumiko Kanoh or Kanou Kumiko). The Unbearable Lightness of Being Hungry has a 2009 vegetarian ramen recipe from the same author. There’s a profile of Yumiko Kano in Metropolis.

We got some very yummy new potatoes from Farmers Market that I cooked up last night, which were 1000x more wonderful than storebought old potatoes.

Exit Biggby heading north to North Campus to Mujo’s, for some time spent writing. Close all of the windows, save all of the documents, publish locally all of the works in progress. North Campus has the virute of frequent free bus service from Central Campus, and it’s far enough away to completely flush all of the thoughts of what I had been doing so I can work on another project.

item.title: lob a postcard: printer sends cards via API
item.description:
Lob.com has an API to send postcards-as-a-service ($0.70 per each, full custom both sides). Details at https://lob.com/services/postcards . It works, but all of the user interface is up to you; if you know a good service for delivering a single full-custom postcard with postage that actually has a user interface and not an API for less than $1.00 each, let me know and I’ll update here.

I’ve started checking in a few tiny utility programs that exercise the Lob API. Look for https://github.com/vielmetti/postcard on Github. The goal at some point is to have a “postcard” application that has a user interface like so.

postcard --to mom --photo cute-kids.jpg --message "they get so big so fast! love ed"

Also in this business is PostalMethods with a Postcard API based on SOAP. That’s not a convenient interface in the languages that I use, but you can look at the API at http://www.postalmethods.com/lp/postcard-api . Their prices for postcards run $1.50 per each or less, with quantity discounts - see http://www.postalmethods.com/pricing for details.

Postful used to have an API for postcards. They were bought by Click2Mail in 2011. Pricing for Click2Mail’s postcards starts at $0.25 per card plus $0.284 postcard, but there’s a $2.00 minimum if you don’t have credits on account. I wasn’t able to determine at first glance whether their REST API applied to onesy-twoesy printing options, though it was clear that if you wanted to send 1000 cards that the pricing would be competitive.

item.title: espresso over ice with a little half and half
item.description:
A simple recipe that you can order from your favorite barista: an espresso shot over ice. Leave enough room to add a spot of half and half. Cold, refreshing, and very strong.

To try: a shot of espresso over shaved ice. I think this is doable at Ann Arbor Farmers Market where you’d go to the stall where a granny is selling shaved ice, and then walk a plain snow cone over to the Roos Roast stand for your espresso shot.

Inspired by a Facebook post from Allen Leibowitz in Texas ordering a snow cone and the surrounding commentary.
